abstract.p: This article introduces a platform for computer-aided engineering-based optimization using a Grid-based environment. Established upon China National Grid (CNGrid) environment, the platform is designed to maximize the efficiency of optimization process while taking advantage of Grid computing. This research provides the grid users with easier access to simulation-based optimization problem, so that they will not be distracted by lower level details and can concentrate on the problem itself. The architecture and the techniques used are thoroughly explained in this article. Practicality of the platform is further validated through application on an optimization project in automotive industry for lightweight design of a body in white.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Grid computing, a close relative to distributed and parallel computing, has been generally accepted as an effective way to implement scientific and engineering projects, especially those that require large-scale simulation and huge database. Inspired by the prospects it was to bring, many Grid computing infrastructures were developed and deployed by governments around the world [1–6]. These developments benefit many scientific and industrial institutions who cannot afford or do not have access to a large local computing centre. Although the advantages of Grid computing has been proved through worldwide application, the number of users in general remains small compared to the forecasts publicly announced in project descriptions and visionary publications [7]. This leads to the question of what measures can be taken to make Grid computing more accessible and applicable to researchers and engineers.

In almost every field of applied science and engineering, the need to solve optimization problem exists in one way or the other. To tackle optimization problem properly, one needs to have a comprehensive understanding of the whole process, from abstraction of the specific problem, through design and realization of optimization algorithm, to allocation of computing resources. In this article, an optimization platform established upon China National Grid (CNGrid) environment that can maximize the efficiency of optimization process while taking advantage of Grid computing is presented. The target of this research is to provide the grid users with easier access to simulation-based optimization problem, so that they will not be distracted by lower level details and can concentrate on the problem itself.

This article is organized as follows: Section 2 discusses the background for the development of an optimization platform using a Grid-based environment; Section 3 presents the general framework, the architecture of the platform, and its functionality; Section 4 presents a case in automotive industry as a demonstration of the applicability of the platform; Finally, the article is concluded with a summary and a brief outlook in Section 5.

sec.title: 2.1 Past work
sec.p: Optimization problem has been the focus of research since the advent of modern computers. Over the years, attempts have been made to address parts of the design optimization problem in a parallel/distributed environment. In 1996, Kim and Zeigler [8] developed a framework for multi-resolution optimization methodology for parallel/distributed simulation environment, which was constructed with multiple clusters hierarchically arranged with each level solving different degrees of abstracted problems. A higher level cluster evaluates a wider search space with low resolution, whereas a lower level cluster investigates a smaller search space which is more promising for containing the global optimum. As the Grid technology received worldwide attention, a number of Grid-based frameworks for optimization were proposed. In 2000, Abramson et al. [9–11] developed a novel tool called Nimrod/O that allows a user to run an arbitrary computational model as the core of a non-linear optimization process. Nimrod/O employs a number of built-in optimization algorithms, and can be executed on a variety of platforms, including distributed clusters and computational grid resources. In 2002, the GEODISE project was carried out by Cox et al. [12, 13] aiming to aid the engineer in the design process by making available a suite of design optimization and search tools, computational fluid dynamics analysis packages integrated with distributed Grid-enabled computing, data, and knowledge resources. In 2007, Lim et al. [14] presented a Hierarchical Parallel Genetic Algorithm (GA) framework using standard Grid technology, providing significant speed-up to evolutionary design optimization in science and engineering. In 2009, Munawar et al. developed the Grid-based Unified Framework for Optimization, a service-oriented architecture compliant problem-solving environment that allows the user to implement/share metaheuristics-based optimization algorithms over a grid [15–17]. Having demonstrated their capability in dealing with various optimization problems, these projects can be a confidence booster for more extensive use of Grid computing, especially in a time when some believe that the grid concept as a whole is on its way to beingreplaced by Cloud computing and other approaches.

sec.title: 2.2 CAE-based optimization demand in industry
sec.p: In engineering fields such as aircraft and automotive design, CAE-based analysis has already been applied extensively. High-fidelity analysis models are adopted to simulate and validate real products, saving a large amount of time and money in product design process. Grid technology that allows a secure and coordinated sharing of globally distributed resources spanning several physical organizations [18] has enabled many enterprises and scientific institutions, especially those small and medium ones who cannot afford large IT infrastructures, to perform realistic simulations. As the role CAE analysis plays in engineering design process becomes more and more important, the need to perform CAE-based optimization is rapidly increased. However, optimization itself usually involves a large number of iterations while searching for an optimum, which makes the process even more time consuming. Furthermore, design and realization of different optimization algorithms can be an annoying job for engineers whose expertise usually lies elsewhere. These inadequacies, if not resolved properly, can be impedance for further development of CAE-based optimization.

In recent years, optimization package such as OPTIMUS and iSight provides an environment in which one can automatically visualize and explore the design space and gain the critical insights into the dynamics of the problem. Taking OPTIMUS for example, it integrates a pool of optimization algorithms, and can link to any simulation code or even legacy system. An engineer can automate the running of simulation-based workflows in a much faster and more convenient manner. However, without adequate computing resources, the optimization work is still very limited.

sec.title: 2.3 Features of the optimization platform
sec.p: The idea of establishing a framework for CAE-based optimization over grid was evolved for the purpose of promoting application of Grid technology by providing grid users with a platform on which they can perform CAE-based optimization in an easy and reliable way. The framework distincts itself from past work for it combines features of popular optimization software and advantages of Grid computing. The characteristics of the framework can be concluded with three points: first of all, based upon Grid environment, this framework has the ability to provide sufficient computational resources, including hardware, software, and resource management capability; second, the framework is provided to grid users as Web service, and processes easy and convenient access for engineers to define optimization process; third, incorporating a large pool of optimization algorithms and interface to various simulation software, the universality of the framework is ensured.

sec.title: 3.1 Overview
sec.p:
The platform is basically a combination of Web services, Optimization service, and Grid computing. Figure 1 shows the general architecture of the optimization framework. The user accesses the optimization platform via web interface, and describes the optimization job he or she wants to undertake. The message received in frontend will be interpreted by the Web server, and exported as a sequence file for optimization job. The optimization service hosting in the master grid is then evoked. After parsing the sequence file, the optimization workflow is initiated, following the commands indicated in the sequence file, including the CAE software the simulation needs to use. The Grid service then begins searching for resources distributed in a heterogeneous environment for the computation. When the simulation finishes in the respective master grid, the CAE output file will be sent back to master grid, for further processing carried out by optimization service. When the optimization job comes to an end, a result file will be generated, and presented to the user via web interface. Fig. 1
Platform architecture

sec.title: 3.2.1 Functionality of Web interaction module
sec.p: The Web interaction module is the only part of the whole framework that interacts directly with the users. It serves as the command listener and job guidance, and enables the grid users to complete a series of actions involved in optimization work, including construction of workflows, specification of objectives and constraints, and selection of optimization algorithms.

The Web interaction module can be accessed by grid users via any usual web browser. As the only part of the framework that the user can communicate with, the module must be able to ‘understand‘ thecommands from the user and respond properly. The functionalities that the module accomplished should include are as follows:

Identity authentication is the first necessary step to ensure the security of the framework. Only the grid users that have been registered in the Grid community have the access to the framework. Once the identity has been authenticated, the user can immediately create an optimization project. Instructions appeared in the web will guide the user through the whole process to finish the optimization task description.

After the user logs into the platform, there will be a list of tasks displaying on the website, indicating necessary steps the user must follow to fully describe the optimization task. At the first stage, the user needs to define the workflow of the whole task. A workflow is conceptually a chart that reveals the dataflow in an optimization task. The interaction Web is illustrated in Fig. 2. Workflow can be defined by simply dragging and connecting the icons listed. Fig. 2
Web interface for workflow definition

After the workflow is defined, the web page will display a list of parameters that needs to be specified bythe user. These parameters include names and domains of the input variables, algebraic representation of constraints and objectives, and selection of optimization algorithms. As the platform is mainly for optimization based on numerical simulation, it is necessary for the user to specify the type of simulation program it uses. Available software resources included in the Grid community will be displayed on the web page, and can be chosen simply by clicking the respective icon. Besides, the user needs to upload an input file used for numerical simulation as well as an output file from where simulation results are extracted. He will then be guided to specify the positions of optimization variables in the input file, and how the output data can be extracted from the output file.

Within a same project the user creates, there can be several parallel optimization jobs listed in a queue. These optimization jobs share a same workflow, but can either be Design of Experiments (DoE) methods or optimization algorithms. In this way, the effectiveness of different optimization algorithms or algorithm parameters can be evaluated in a parallel way. After the optimization task has been specified, the job can be submitted by the user, and the next module will be activated.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Techniques to achieve the functionality
sec.p: The functionality of the Web interaction module is mostly achieved by Java Beans hosted in the Web server. A number of Java Beans are generated to process the information received from the client. As the ultimate goal of the Web interaction module is to provide an instructive file for the optimization server, it is natural that all the Java Beans, though with different levels of complexity, will result in modification or implementation of the instruction file. To make the instruction file easy to modify, and at the same time easy for the optimization server to parse, an XML (XML, eXtensible Markup Language) file appears to be the most promising.

The instruction file in XML format is standardized, so that it can provide a consistent interface for different Java Beans as well as the optimization server. The main structure of the instruction file consists of both mandatory and optional elements. The mandatory elements are always included in the instruction file, while the optional ones appear depending on user’s choice. Figure 3 shows the mandatory elements in the instruction file. Fig. 3
Mandatory elements in instruction file

Here, the element < FACTORS > is for definition of the input variables that are to be set during each experiment. Within the < FACTORS > , there can be a number of ‘ < FACTOR > ’s, each representing asingle input variable of the experiment. The < FACTOR > element consists of several parameters and attributes that define the input variable. Atypical < FACTOR > specification is as shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4
Typical < FACTOR > specification

Similarly, the element < Responses > is for definition of the output variables that need to be extracted from the simulation output files. In addition, lower and upper constraints, target values, target weights, and sensitivity weights can be specified. The element < EXPERIMENT > is for definition of the experiment to be executed, and < DATAFLOW > is for definition of sequence of the workflow which is to be followed during the process.

Optional elements include < REUSE > , < DEPENDENCIES > , and < REJECT>. They are not always contained in an instruction file but come outonly when necessary. For example, element < REJECT > appears only when the user defined the reject rule that should be used to determine whether or not the experiments would be performed. They are very convenient to define a constrained DoE, but often ignored for optimization runs. As the mandatory elements, these optional ones also have sub-elements or sub-tags to specify the respective details.

Besides modifying and implementing the instruction file for optimization, there is another important function that the Java Beans achieve in the Web interaction module, that is, to make input and output templates for the CAE simulation. The input template differs from the uploaded input file, in that it contains special characters which indicate positions and formats of the input variables. The output template is essentially the same as the uploaded output file, only that it has a different file suffix to identify itself as a template. The templates are stored in the data server via Java Data Base Connectivity.

sec.title: 3.3 Optimization module
sec.p: The optimization module is hosted in Grid environment, as shown in Fig. 1. Basically, it can be divided into two parts, the optimization engine deployed in the master Grid (or Grid server), and the Grid nodes that perform CAE simulations. The former is analogous to a controlling centre which decides how the optimization job runs, and the latter is like a group of servants that do the laborious work.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Optimization server
sec.p:
The optimization server is the core of the platform that controls the running of optimization job. The relationship between sub-parts of the optimization engine is illustrated in Fig. 5. The server initiates the job by parsing the instruction file sent by the Web server. The characteristics of the XML file make this parsing process convenient using the Java Dom4J library. Fig. 5
Optimization server

A dataflow that represents a single experiment sequence is first generated by parsing the < DATAFLOW > element in the instruction file. It describes the different steps that have to be performed to execute one experiment. In optimization manager, the steps involved are carried out by calling for corresponding programs. The steps frequently occurred in the process are listed below.
Make_input_file: creation of an input file from the template file
Start_simulation: start CAE simulation using the software specified in < DATAFLOW>
Abstract_results: abstract results from output file generated after simulation
Collect_data: record input and output data for further study

While the < DATAFLOW > defines sequence within a single experiment, the information contained in the < EXPERIMENT > indicates how different workflows are managed within an optimization job. Associated with this element is the algorithm pool which contains a number of DoE methods and optimization algorithms. For optimization algorithms that are based upon population search, such as GA, and all the experiment design methods which decide design variables in advance, the workflows can always be parallelized, which makes the Grid environment valuable. Moreover, together with the input variable information contained in element < FACTORS > , the optimization server will decide the variable value for each run automatically.

sec.title: 3.3.2 Resource deployment
sec.p: Another important piece of information contained in the instruction file is the CAE simulation package used for the experiment. Once the optimization server gets to know the name of the software, the CAE simulation scheduler will begin its job. According to available resources existing in the Grid community, the CAE simulation scheduler will decide which Grid nodes to use for the experiments. Though they may be geographically distributed, Grid members within the community have similar expertise, and their computation capability is pre-registered as a part of the community agreement for easy resource locating.

The scheduler does its job by three main steps. The first is to screen the resources available within the Grid community that consists of geographically distributed Grid nodes, providing CAE simulation services. The screening standard includes the type of CAE simulation the node can provide and the number of central processing units required for a single run, and thus varies according to specific CAE task. For instance, the grid which can host simulation using ANSYS with only four cores is considered available for a simulation that needs two cores, but not for a task that requires eight cores.

After the screening process, the scheduler will give an evaluation for each available node within the Grid community. The Quality of Service (QoS) of each node is related to the overall time a single task takes on that node. The less the time is, the higher the quality. The overall time consists of two parts, the time used for computing and the time for transferring data files between optimization server and Grid node. sec.title: 4.1 Problem description
sec.p:
To improve the fuel economy of a newly designed car, the car maker wants to reduce the weight of body in white (BIW) before production, by replacing the material of some parts with high-strength steel. To validate the design, roof crush tests following the FMVSS-216 standard [19] will be carried out on a car model for several times. Still it is not feasible in today’s automotive industry to wait for a product to be fully manufactured before subjecting it to such tests. This brings the use of numerical simulation using finite element (FE) methods. The FE model of the BIW is shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6
FE model of BIW

The model consists of 794 923 elements and 853 386 nodes. Loading is applied through rigid plate, oriented as per FMVSS-216 requirements. The standard FMVSS216 requires that when a large steel test plate is forced down onto the roof of a vehicle, simulating contact with the ground in rollover crashes, the vehicle roof structure must withstand a force equivalent to 2.5 times the unloaded weight of the vehicle without the test plate, moving more than 127 mm. The roof crush test is simulated using the commercial package LS-DYNA. A single run on eight CPU computing nodes costs about 10 h.

sec.title: 4.3 Optimization process
sec.p:
Knowing that the thickness of each part is explicitly written in the input key file of LS-DYNA, and the results representing the force the vehicle roof withstands can be extracted by rules from the output file of the simulation, it is not difficult to propose a flowchart that illustrates the dataflow during the optimization process, as shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 7
Flowchart of the optimization process

As the BIW model is constituted of hundreds of parts, it is crucial to first find out which parts are to be replaced by high-strength steel. Twenty-three parts of interest were selected that are supposed to be more sensitive than others to the roof crush capability. Among these 23 parts, ten are symmetrical; therefore, the input variables are reduced to 13. To keep the manufacturing budget within a reasonable domain, not all these 23 parts will be replaced by high-strength steel. Sensitivity analysis usually achieved by DoE is first to be done to narrow down the dominating variables, with an optimization process following afterwards.

Keeping the flowchart in mind, one can easily create the workflow for the sensitivity analysis and optimization process via Web interactive module. An input key file for running the LS-DYNA as well as an output file containing the plate force information is uploaded, so that the variables for the analysis can be located and extracted. For the DoE part, the Latin Hypercube Sampling method is selected, with the total experiments number being 60. Results obtained from DoE reveal the sensitivity of these variables to the roof crush capability and total weight. Six variables that are more sensible are selected for optimization, and the corresponding parts are replaced with high-strength steel. Using the same workflow with less input variables, global optimization based on differential evolution algorithm is performed. Optimization process terminates when the convergence criterion is met, after 6 generations with 30 being the population number. Table 1 shows the optimal thickness of the parts whose materials are replaced. The optimal design leads to a weight reduction of 8.63 kg, which is about 19.5 per cent compared with the original one. sec.title: 4.4 Results and discussion
sec.p:
Before optimization starts, Grid nodes within the community are screened for optimization. One designates 16 CPUs for a single simulation in this case; therefore, Grid nodes that provide LS-DYNA simulation service with more than 16 available CPUs are considered usable. Three nodes are discovered: node A can host 16 parallel simulations, and the CPU frequency is 1.9 GHz; node B can host 4 parallel simulations, and the CPU frequency is 3 GHz; node C can host 3 parallel simulations, and the CPU frequency is 2.4 GHz. According to the above information as well as the data file size and Internet bandwidth, the estimated computing time and the QoS of each node can be calculated, which is 0.09, 0.15, and 0.12, respectively. This shows that node B is the most preferable one for simulation. The optimization scheduler would follow the algorithm described in Section 3.3.2 to minimize the overall computing time. Figure 9 shows the distribution of the DoE tasks based on the estimated QoS. It reveals that the overall time for running 60 parallel simulation is about 32 h. Fig. 9
DoE task distribution

The statics of the case stated provides convenient evidence to the practicality of the platform. For optimization based upon large-scale simulation, there is no doubt that such a platform is a proper choice.

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sec.p: In this article, the background for the development of an optimization platform over Grid has been introduced. Taking advantage of Grid computing, the platform is designed to provide industry users an innovative tool for optimization work based upon numerical simulation. This article has described the architecture of the platform, the functions of each module, and how the functions are achieved. A real optimization job for lightweight design of BIW employing LS-DYNA as the CAE software is tested on the platform. The case study has illustrated that it is possible to carry out optimization work from the Web interface, using algorithms provided by the platform, while taking into account the highly parallel and sharing features of the Grid.

However, efforts in the establishment of the platform are regarded as preliminary by the authors of this study. One needs to develop more functions of the platform in such an environment, in particular issues such as post-processing of the optimization statistics, integration of self-developed codes for simulation, so that the workflow can be more flexible. The platform is currently a general purpose tool that allows a new workflow to be executed without the need for original code development. The simulation commands and the way inputs and outputs be extracted from files are already encapsulated. However, this will lower the flexibility of the definition of the workflow because the extraction rules can be varied according to different optimization tasks. One wishes to implement a post-processing module in the optimization server, and visualize the results of the experiments on the Web. The platform would be more appealing if the optimization server can also create metamodels for CAE-based design utilizing the data obtained from experimental design. It is also possible to develop an interface in the optimization server, so that the user can use self-developed optimization algorithm or codes for numerical simulation. These issues are the topic of ongoing research.
